title: French radical far-right groups call for 'sacred union' after activist's death
subhed: The march planned for Quentin Deranque this Saturday in Lyon could be an opportunity for ultra-right groups to unite around the far-right activist, who has been elevated to the status of political martyr. But far-right leading figure Jordan Bardella ordered his party's elected officials not to attend.
byline: By Corentin Lesueur and Abel Mestre

title: Paris mayoral election campaign gets bogged down in controversy
Former Prince Andrew arrested for several hours by police in historic event for the UK
Appeals trial for murder of Samuel Paty: Abdelhakim Sefrioui believes everyone is to blame, except himself
subhed: The Islamist activist was unable, during Thursday's hearing, to acknowledge any wrongdoing in the fatal hate campaign against the history and geography teacher in 2020. Immune to self-doubt, he instead highlighted the responsibility of the French state.

title: Bovine skin disease: After eight months of tension, French health crisis appears to be ending
subhed: With no new cases of this disease identified since January 2 and two million cattle vaccinated, the last regulated zone still in place is expected to be lifted on Friday.

title: 'The French economy is paradoxically experiencing a renewed sense of optimism'
subhed: Despite a worrying national and international context, there have been several positive signals from business leaders, notably driven by the defense and aerospace industries, observes Le Monde journalist Béatrice Madeline.

title: With 'American Obituary,' U2 returns to the battle, taking aim at Trump
subhed: The Irish band wrote this protest song in the aftermath of the death of Renee Good, who was killed by US federal agents in Minneapolis. It is one of six tracks on their new EP, 'Days of Ash,' which also addresses Iran, the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and the war in Ukraine.

title: Ukraine Paralympics team to boycott opening ceremony over Russian flag decision
Venezuelan parliament unanimously passes amnesty law
Trump's Board of Peace opens with $10 billion pledge and troops for Gaza
Real or faux, vintage or new, fur is no longer hiding
In Dhaka, Sheikh Hasani's palace has been turned into a museum honoring victims of the July 2024 uprising
USA beat Canada 2-1 to win Olympic women's ice hockey gold medal
Italy, the UK and Japan hope to bring Germany on board their next-generation fighter jet project
byline: By Olivier Pinaud and Cécile Ducourtieux (London, correspondent)

title: 'Lawless zones around Israel are the result of the Pax Judaica made possible by uncontested military hegemony'
Eric Dane, 'Grey's Anatomy' star and ALS awareness advocate, dies at 53
Trump sees 'maximum' 15 days for Iran to make deal
Tom Fletcher: 'Anyone who says the UN is dead should spend some time with my colleagues in Sudan or DRC'
byline: Interview by Claire Gatinois and Philippe Ricard

title: Trump says he's ordering release of data on UFOs and aliens
Gaza's local authorities massively underreported deaths, says international research team
subhed: The first independent field study on Gaza to not involve local authorities, published in The Lancet Global Health on Wednesday, concludes that the number of violent deaths linked to the conflict has been underreported by about 35%.

title: Epstein scandal divides the MAGA world and weakens Trump
subhed: Since the latest release of files on the sexual predator, supporters of the US president have questioned the administration's lack of transparency and confusing communication.

title: Xavier Dolan, filmmaker: "Where does the idea that artists should 'stay out of politics' come from?"
subhed: A controversy is stirring at this year's Berlinale. At their opening press conference, the jury members declined to comment on the situation in Palestine, with their president, Wim Wenders, arguing that cinema should 'stay out of politics.' Canadian director Xavier Dolan responds to him in an op-ed for Le Monde.

title: 'The spectacle of European disunity in the face of pressure from both the United States and China is infuriating'
Patrick Artus: 'The unpopular reforms France nevertheless needs to undertake'
Paul Magnette, political scientist: 'If Trump's camp felt superior, why try and divide Europe?'
